key_insight: Using large language models in scholarly writing creates a provenance problem: generated text, citations, and edits often lack traceable origin, threatening accountability, reproducibility, and the integrity of the scientific record.
problem_solved: Identifies and characterizes the challenge of undocumented, non-auditable LLM contributions to manuscripts and proposes a framework of technical and policy measures to restore provenance and accountability.
method: Conceptual analysis that defines provenance dimensions for scholarly outputs (source, transformation, attribution, timestamp).
Illustrative examples/case studies showing hallucinated citations and opaque edits in LLM-assisted drafts.
Prescriptive recommendations combining metadata standards, logging/timestamps, model attribution, and cryptographic/technical controls for auditability.
impact: Prompts AI/ML practitioners, publishers, and researchers to adopt provenance-first workflows (machine-readable metadata, disclosure, and audit trails) to preserve reproducibility, trust, and ethical accountability in LLM-assisted research.
visual_elements: Provenance chain diagram: human author → LLM (with model/version) → edits → final manuscript, annotated with timestamps and metadata.
Side-by-side example: hallucinated citation vs. verified source to show risk and detection.
Flowchart of technical solutions: metadata standards → logging → cryptographic signatures → publisher ingestion.
Policy checklist / icon set for stakeholders (authors, reviewers, publishers, toolmakers) showing required disclosures and controls.
paper_title: LLM use in scholarly writing poses a provenance problem
paper_authors: Brian D. Earp, Haotian Yuan, Julian Koplin, Sebastian Porsdam Mann
